Fig. 1 (a) CO2 conversion, (b) CH3OH selectivity, and (c) CH3OH yield over Mn0 at a reaction gas flow rate of 30 mL (STP) min−1 under varying reaction pressures from 1 to 4 MPa. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) CO2 conversion, (b) CH3OH selectivity, and (c) CH3OH yield under equilibrium conditions calculated using COCO/ChemSep, assuming a feed gas composition of CO2/H2/N2 = 1/3/1 (v/v/v). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) CO2 conversion, (b) CH3OH selectivity, and (c) CH3OH yield over Mn0, Mn5 and Mn10 at a reaction gas flow rate of 30 mL (STP) min−1 and a pressure of 4 MPa. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Arrhenius plots for CO2-to-methanol hydrogenation over Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 at 1 MPa. (b) Methanol selectivity at different CO2 conversions for Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10. Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts are well known for promoting methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation. In this study, the effect of Mn addition to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 was investigated. XPS analysis revealed that the as-prepared catalysts contained both Mn3 + and Mn4+ species, whereas only Mn3+ was present after hydrogen reduction at 300 °C. These results suggest that Mn species existed as Mn2O3 under reaction conditions. Furthermore, the addition of Mn led to a decrease in the crystallite size of metallic Cu, indicating that Mn species promoted the dispersion of Cu species. This increased dispersion is considered to enhance the number of active sites on the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst. In addition, the presence of Mn species enhanced the methanol selectivity by suppressing the undesirable methanol decomposition to CO. As a result, the Mn-modified Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst achieved a methanol yield of 9.3 % at 4 MPa and 250 °C. Graphical abstract Keywords Methanol Copper Manganese Carbon dioxide Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is an important technology for mitigating CO2 emissions and achieving a sustainable society in the future. The catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol involves the following reactions. First, CO2 is directly hydrogenated to methanol (Eq. 1). Second, CO2 undergoes the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction, producing carbon monoxide and steam (Eq. 2). Third, the thus-formed CO is further hydrogenated to methanol (Eq. 3). Low-temperature operation minimizes CO production via the endothermic RWGS reaction and enhances the methanol yield, defined as the product of CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. For CO2 hydrogenation, activating the thermodynamically stable CO2 molecule remains a significant challenge. These considerations underscore the importance of developing catalysts specifically designed for CO2 hydrogenation. (1) CO 2 + 3 H 2 → C H 3 OH + H 2 O ∆ r H o = − 49.4 kJ mol − 1 (2) CO 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O ∆ r H o = + 41.0 kJ mol − 1 (3) CO + 2 H 2 → C H 3 OH ∆ r H o = − 90.4 kJ mol − 1 In the 1960s, Imperial Chemical Industries installed Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, establishing Cu-based catalysts as the standard for methanol synthesis. At that time, methanol was synthesized from syngas (a mixture of CO and H2), and thus, Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 were optimized for CO hydrogenation rather than CO2 hydrogenation. [1] Although Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 has been studied as CO2 hydrogenation catalysts, [2–5] several other Cu-based catalysts have also been reported: Cu/Al2O3, [6] Cu/CeO2/TiO2, [7] Cu/ZrO2, [8–10] Cu/Ga2O3/ZrO2. [11] Among Cu-based catalysts, Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 has emerged as one of the most promising catalysts. For example, Arena et al. reported the combination of Cu/ZnO with various metal oxides, such as Al2O3, ZrO2, and CeO2, and found the catalytic activity order to be Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 > Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 > Cu/ZnO/CeO2. [12] They considered that Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst benefits from the synergistic effects of both Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZrO2 systems as follows. [13] In the Cu/ZnO catalyst, the formation of Cu-Zn alloy [2,3] and/or Cu-ZnO interfacial sites [4] upon contact between Cu and the ZnO surface contributes to the creation of new active sites. In the Cu/ZrO2 system, Cu facilitates H2 activation while ZrO2 adsorbs CO2, enabling the two activated species to interact at the Cu-ZrO2 interface, thereby forming methanol. [9] Given that ZrO2 is a basic oxide with a high surface area, it plays a crucial role in enhancing the performance of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts. Wang et al. reported that the ZnO–ZrO2 interface, which constitutes the third type of interfacial site in the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst system, serves as the main active site for CO2 adsorption and subsequent hydrogenation. [14] Promoters for Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 have also been studied; however, a unified consensus on their effects has yet to be established. When a small amount of Al2O3 was added to the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst, partial substitution of Zr4+ with Al3+ occurred, leading to the formation of Cu-rich hydrotalcite-like compounds that governed the dispersion of Cu species during the reaction. [15] Witoon et al. demonstrated that the addition of graphene oxide to a Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst improved a methanol yield of up to 76 % was achieved at 200 °C and 20 atm, probably because the graphene oxide facilitated hydrogen spillover, thereby increasing the surface hydrogen coverage. [16] Although the effect of Al2O3 and SiO2 addition was not discussed, a Cu/ZnO/ZrO2/Al2O3/SiO2 catalyst achieved a methanol production rate of 580 g h−1 under conditions of 523 K, 5 MPa, and a space velocity of 10,000 h−1, maintaining stable performance over 1,000 h. [17] In this study, we focus on manganese oxides (MnO x ) as a promoter for Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. To date, only a few studies have investigated the role of MnO x for methanol synthesis catalysts. Słoczńyski et al. proposed that the redox and acid-base properties of MnO x facilitate the dissociative adsorption of CO2. [18] Notably, the addition of MnO x to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 was also found to enhance the dispersion of Cu species. [18] Wang et al. demonstrated that Cu species originating from Cu1.5Mn1.5O4 spinel-type oxides in Cu-Mn-Zn/ZrO2 catalysts effectively promote methanol production. [19] However, no definitive conclusion was drawn regarding which factor plays the dominant role. In the present study, we systematically examined the effect of Mn addition to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 and reported that it is the enhancement of Cu dispersion and suppression of undesirable methanol decomposition to CO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cu(NO3)2･3H2O (Fujifilm Wako), Zn(NO3)2･6H2O (Fujifilm Wako), ZrO(NO3)2･2H2O (Fujifilm Wako), Mn(NO3)2･4H2O (Sigma-Adlrich), and Na2CO3 (Fujifilm Wako) were used as received. The catalysts were prepared by a coprecipitation method. Solution A was made by dissolving metal nitrate in 40 mL of distilled water. Solution B was made by dissolving Na2CO3 in 40 mL of distilled water at 1.1 times the total metal ion molarity of solution A. Both solutions were added dropwise into 200 mL of distilled water at 60 °C under stirring and then aged for 30 min. The pH values of Solution A, Solution B, and their mixture were 0.8, 12, and 7.2, respectively. The resulting slurry was centrifuged, washed with water, dried at 100 °C, and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h. The metal loadings and abbreviations of catalysts were summarized in Table 1 and Figure S1. The amount of MnO2 in the catalyst was increased by correspondingly decreasing the amount of ZrO2. 2.2 Performance test The catalytic performance was evaluated using a stainless-made fixed bed tubular reactor. The catalyst powder was pelletized at 20 MPa, then crushed into particles ranging from 1.18 to 1.7 mm in size. 500 mg of the catalyst grain and 6 g of quartz sand were put into the catalyst bed. The catalyst bed temperature was monitored by a K-type thermocouple positioned at the center of the catalyst layer. A reaction gas mixture (CO2/H2/N2 = 1/3/1, v/v/v) was fed into the catalyst bed at a flow rate of 15–50 mL(STP) min−1, at 275 °C and P MPa (P = 1–4 MPa) for 2 h. After that, the reactor was cooled from 275 °C to 200 °C. The outlet gas composition was analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC2014ATF). CO2 conversion (X CO2), CH3OH selectivity (S CH3OH), and CH3OH yield (Y CH3OH) were calculated from the following equations. (4) X CO 2 = 1 − F out , CO 2 F in , CO 2 (5) S CH 3 OH = F out , CH 3 OH F out , CO + F out , CH 3 OH (6) Y CH 3 OH = X CO 2 S CH 3 OH In these equations, F in, i and F out, i are the inlet and outlet gas flow rate of i species [mL(STP) min−1]. In addition, the equilibrium values of X CO2 and S CH3OH were estimated using a Gibbs reactor module implemented in COCO, which is based on the CAPE-OPEN framework. The Peng–Robinson equation of state was applied for gas-phase calculations, assuming a feed gas composition of CO2/H2/N2 = 1/3/1 (v/v/v). To estimate the apparent activation energy for CO2 conversion, Arrhenius plots were constructed based on the assumption of a first-order reaction with respect to CO2, where the reaction rate depends on the CO2 partial pressure. Under this assumption, the rate constant k [s⁻¹ ], residence time τ [s], and X CO2 are related by Eq. 7. [20] In order to suppress the influence of mass transport limitations, only data obtained under low-conversion conditions (X CO2 < 20 %) were considered. The apparent activation energy (E a, [kJ mol−1]) was then determined using the Arrhenius equation (Eq. 8), where A is the pre-exponential factor, R is the universal gas constant (8.31 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹), and T is the absolute reaction temperature [K]. (7) k τ = X CO 2 1 + X CO 2 (8) k = A e − E a RT 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) . The X-ray diffraction of the crystal structure was conducted using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer. A glass plate was utilized to hold the sample powder, which was then placed within the diffractometer. The X-ray source utilized was Cu Kα, with an acceleration voltage of 40 kV and a current of 20 mA. The crystallite size of the Cu (111) plane (D Cu111 [nm]) was calculated using the Scherrer equation (Eq. 9), (9) D Cu 111 = K λ β cos θ where K is the shape factor (0.89), λ is the wavelength of Cu Kα radiation (0.154 [nm]), β is the full width at half maximum [rad], and θ is the Bragg angle [rad]. N 2 adsorption . A N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm at 77 K for the samples were measured by a Microtrac BEL BELSORP mini-II. These samples were pretreated using a Microtrac BEL BELPREP-vacII at 150 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The specific surface area and pore volume were calculated using the Brunauer- Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) . The determination of metal loadings was carried out via XRF analysis using PANalytical Epsilon 1 instrumentation. The acquired data was analyzed using the fundamental parameter method, employing Omnian software (PANalytical). Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) . STEM was performed on an atomic resolution analytical STEM (JEOL JEM-ARM200F) equipped with a spherical aberration corrector for a STEM probe. The particles were dispersed in ethanol, and the suspension was deposited onto a grid (Quantifoil R3.5/1 200 mesh). Elemental maps of Cu, Zn, Zr, and Mn were recorded using an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) detector. T emperature programmed reduction by H 2 (H 2 -TPR). H2-TPR measurements were performed using a BELCAT II (MicrotracBEL) instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The sample (0.05 g) was heated at 300 °C for 120 min in a flow of Ar (30 mL min−1) and cooled to 50 °C. The feed gas was changed to 5 % H2/Ar (30 mL min−1), and the sample was heated at 5.0 °C min−1. Temperature programmed desorption of CO 2 (CO 2 -TPD). CO2 adsorption behavior was analyzed by CO2-TPD using a BELCAT II instrument (MicrotracBEL) equipped with a TCD. A 0.1 g sample was first pretreated at 300 °C for 30 min in a 5 %H2/Ar gas flow, followed by an additional 30 min at 300 °C under He. After cooling to 50 °C, the sample was exposed to a 14 % CO2/He gas mixture for 30 min. The gas was then switched to He at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1, and the sample was heated at a rate of 5 °C min−1 for desorption analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) . The oxidation states of Zn, Cu, Mn, and Zr were determined by XPS (JEOL JPS-9010MC instrument with a Mg Kα radiation source). The samples were reduced in a stream of 5 %H2/Ar at 300 °C for 30 min and then transferred to the instrument chamber without exposure to air. Binding energies were referenced to the Zn 2p3/2 peak (1022.0 eV). To evaluate the oxidation states of Cu and Zn, we calculated the Auger parameters (α’ [eV]) according to the following equations. (10) α ′ Cu = Binding energy of Cu 2 p 3 / 2 + Kinetic energy of Cu LMM (11) α ′ Zn = Binding energy of Zn 2 p 3 / 2 + Kinetic energy of Zn LMM Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectra were recorded using the 532 nm emission line of a 15 ps pulsed laser (Talisker Ultra 355–4, Coherent) as the excitation source. A typical laser power of 300 mW was used. The sample was placed in a glass capillary, and the signal of the 90° scattering component was collected using a 20 × ultraviolet microscope objective lens (Thorlabs) and delivered to a monochromator (Triax320, Horiba). Rayleigh lines were eliminated using a long-pass filter (Semrock). Signals were detected using a charge-coupled device (CCD) detector (Spec-10; Princeton Instruments). The acquisition time for one spectrum was 300 s (1 s exposure, 30 times accumulation, and 10 spectra were averaged). The emission lines of Hg and Ne lamps were used for wavenumber calibration. The difference in the channel-to-channel sensitivities of the CCD detector was compensated for by considering the intensity spectrum of a tungsten lamp (BWTEK). Prereduction of Mn0 and Mn10 was performed in 5 %H₂/Ar at 300 °C for 30 min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 In this study, we focused on Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts with ZnO and ZrO2 loadings of 9 wt% and 35 wt%, respectively, hereafter denoted as Mn0. This specific composition was selected as a benchmark for subsequent Mn addition studies, as it exhibited the highest Y CH3OH, resulting from a favorable balance between X CO2 and S CH3OH. As described below, the optimal composition of the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst was determined by varying the ZnO-to-ZrO2 ratio. The composition was confirmed by XRF analysis and is provided in the legend of Figure S1. Figure S1a shows the CO2 conversion plotted against the reaction temperature over a series of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts. With increasing ZrO2 content from 0 to 29 wt%, the CO2 conversion curve shifted upward, indicating that the catalytic activity was enhanced. When the ZrO2 content increased further, the performance declined. In contrast, S CH3OH was dramatically increased once the ZrO2 content reached 35 wt% or higher (Figure S1b). As a result, Y CH3OH (calculated as the product of CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity) reached its maximum at a ZrO2 loading of 35 wt% (Figure S1c). 3.2 Effect of Mn addition on CO2 hydrogenation over Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 Next, the pressure dependency of Mn0 was investigated. With increasing pressure from 1 to 4 MPa, X CO2 increased significantly ( Fig. 1 a). For example, X CO2 at 250 °C increased from 7 % at 1 MPa to 18 % at 4 MPa. This trend is similar to that observed in the equilibrium data ( Fig. 2 a). However, compared to the equilibrium, X CO2 values were much lower at 200–225 °C, indicating that CO2 conversion is limited in the low-temperature region. Meanwhile, the sum of the selectivities for methanol and CO was 100 %, because no other products were detected in appreciable amounts. S CH3OH gradually decreased between 200 and 275 °C (Fig. 1 b). This trend appears to contradict thermodynamic predictions, as the equilibrium S CH3OH steadily increases with increasing pressure (Fig. 2 b). Notably, all experimental S CH3OH values were significantly higher than the equilibrium values. In this reaction, CO2-to-methanol hydrogenation (Eq. 1) and CO formation via the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS, Eq. 2) reaction and methanol decomposition (i.e., the reverse of Eq. 3) proceed simultaneously. Hence, methanol is regarded as an intermediate species in CO2 hydrogenation. The high S CH3OH values below 250 °C indicate that the system do not reach equilibrium under the tested conditions, and that the contribution of CO2-to-methanol hydrogenation was greater than that predicted by equilibrium. Although Y CH3OH increases with increasing pressure (Fig. 1 c), it does not reach the equilibrium Y CH3OH value (Fig. 2 c). Here, the effect of Mn addition to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 on CO₂-to-methanol hydrogenation was investigated using Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10. Regardless of the Mn loading, the Mn-containing catalysts exhibited similar reaction trends. X CO2 for Mn5 reached 20 % at 250 °C, which was higher than that of Mn0 ( Fig. 3 a). In contrast, X CO2 for Mn10 was similar to that of Mn0. Interestingly, the Mn-containing catalysts exhibited S CH3OH of approximately 50 %, regardless of the reaction temperature (Fig. 3 b). As a result, they showed a high Y CH3OH, particularly at 250 °C (Fig. 3 c). A comparable trend was observed at a reaction pressure of 1 MPa, as shown in Figures S2 a-c. In addition, the long-term stability of Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 over a period of 2 days is shown in Figure S3. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic performances of previously reported Cu-based catalysts, along with the newly developed Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 catalysts, for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. All reactions were carried out at approximately 250 °C under pressures ranging from 1 to 5 MPa. Among the catalysts investigated, when comparing those with space velocity (SV) values around 3,600 L h−1 g−1 or 3,800 h−1, Mn5 exhibits notably high X CO2 of 20 %. This is the most distinctive feature of Mn5. A comparison of the space-time yields of methanol (STY CH3OH) indicates that Mn5 achieves values comparable to those of previously reported catalysts. Furthermore, operating under higher SV conditions (10,000–20,000 h−1) markedly enhances STY CH3OH. To clearly establish the advantage of Mn5, evaluation of its catalytic performance at higher SV values will be essential, and this will be undertaken in future work. 3.3 Investigation of the reaction mechanism from kinetics results The effect of Mn on the reaction mechanism is of particular interest. It is known that Cu/MnO x catalysts are active for RWGS reaction. [28] Therefore, it is conceivable that the Cu/MnO x interface may facilitate CO formation via a route inaccessible on Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 alone. In this scenario, the generated CO could be subsequently hydrogenated to methanol on the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2. If this CO-forming route is active on Mn-added Cu/ZnO/ZrO2, the dominant reaction pathway may differ from that of the Mn-free catalyst. As a result, E a for CO2 consumption could be influenced by the presence of Mn. To explore this possibility, Arrhenius plots were constructed using X CO2 values obtained at 1 MPa for the Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 catalysts ( Fig. 4 a). Although Y CH3OH was increased by nearly a factor of two upon Mn addition (Table 2), E a for all three catalysts remained nearly constant for all three catalysts, ranging from 45 to 48 kJ mol−1, with minimal variation regardless of Mn content. It should be noted that the E a does not allow us to draw any clear conclusions about the influence of Mn on the reaction pathway. Nevertheless, the Arrhenius plots shift upward upon with the addition of Mn to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2, suggesting an increase in A (pre-exponential factor), in other words, an enhancement in the number of active sites. Although the overall reaction mechanism may be complex, it can be considered that Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 follow a similar reaction pathway, in which CO2 is first converted to methanol (Eq. 1) and subsequently to CO (the reverse of Eq. 3). This is supported by the observation that, with increasing contact time (W/F), both X CO2 and CO selectivity increased, while methanol selectivity decreased ( Fig. 5). [10,29] Fig. 4 b shows the relationship between X CO2 and S CH3OH, where the X CO2 values were adjusted by varying the contact time. According to our previous study, [10,29] the position of each trend line reflects the quality of the active sites on each catalyst. Compared with Mn0, the trend lines for Mn5 and Mn10 were located higher, indicating improved S CH3OH. For example, in the X CO2 range of 8.5 ± 0.3 %, S CH3OH for Mn0 was approximately 40 %, whereas Mn5 and Mn10 exhibited higher values of 45–48 %. This suggests that the presence of Mn slightly suppressed the decomposition of methanol. 3.4 Characterization of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts with Mn addition Fig. 6 presents the HAADF-STEM images and corresponding elemental mappings of the developed catalysts. In the case of the as-prepared Mn0 (Fig. 6 a), the elemental distributions of Cu and Zn appear to be largely overlapped, whereas Zr is distributed separately, suggesting partial segregation. The observed particles are aggregated, with diameters ranging from 10 to 20 nm. After the reaction, the spent Mn0 catalyst (Fig. 6 b) shows significant particle growth, particularly in the Cu-containing regions, with particle sizes exceeding 25 nm. This indicates that Cu species underwent sintering during the reaction process. In contrast, the as-prepared Mn10 catalyst (Fig. 6 c) displays well-overlapped elemental mappings of Cu, Zn, Zr, and Mn, implying a more homogeneous distribution of the metal species. The particle size is slightly smaller, at approximately 10–20 nm, comparable to that of the as-prepared Mn0. Remarkably, in the spent Mn10 sample (Fig. 6 d), no obvious sintered particles (e.g., Cu-containing particles larger than 25 nm) are observed. The Cu-containing particles remain in the 10–20 nm range, suggesting that Mn addition effectively suppresses Cu sintering during the reaction. The difference among Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 is evident in their specific surface areas (SSA), as determined by N₂ adsorption measurements (Table 1). Mn0 exhibited an SSA of 101 m2 g−1, whereas the Mn-containing catalysts (Mn5 and Mn10) showed significantly higher values, around 145 m2 g−1. These results suggest that the incorporation of Mn contributed to an increase in surface area, which may be beneficial for catalytic performance. Figure S4 shows the CO2-TPD profiles of Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10. The Mn0 profile exhibited a single desorption peak at approximately 700 °C. Except for the peak, the overall shapes of the profiles were similar across all samples. Interestingly, the total peak area in the temperature range of 50–800 °C was approximately 2.0 × 106 μV °C g−1, regardless of the catalyst composition. This indicates that the total amount of basic oxide surface sites, such as those from ZrO2 and MnO x , was not significantly affected by the addition of MnO x to CuO/ZnO/ZrO2. Therefore, the observed increase in the specific surface area upon MnO x addition is expected to be attributable to an enhancement in the dispersion or surface area of the Cu and Zn species rather than changes in the basic oxide components. Fig. 7 shows the XRD patterns of the as-prepared and spent catalysts. In the as-prepared samples (Fig. 7 a), diffraction peaks corresponding to CuO were clearly observed, along with a broad halo peak centered around 33°, indicating the presence of amorphous or poorly crystalline components. Notably, the intensity of the CuO peaks diminished with increasing Mn loading, suggesting a reduction in CuO crystallinity or dispersion of Cu species. After the reaction, the spent catalysts exhibited the emergence of sharp peaks attributed to metallic Cu at 2θ = 43° and 51°, along with the persistence of the halo peak. These changes suggest that CuO was reduced to metallic Cu during the pre-treatment and reaction stages conducted under the CO2/H2/N2 gas mixture, which is consistent with the emergence of metallic Cu peaks in the XRD patterns. Importantly, the crystallite size of metallic Cu (111) calculated via the Scherrer equation (Table 1) decreased from 17 nm to 10 nm with increasing Mn content, indicating that Mn addition effectively suppresses Cu sintering. In the case of the spent Mn10 catalyst, additional unidentified peaks appeared at approximately 32° and 53°, suggesting the formation of new crystalline phases, the nature of which remains to be determined. Next, we measured the Raman spectra of Mn0 and Mn10 under 532 nm excitation ( Fig. 8). In all spectra, four characteristic peaks were observed at 334, 372, 472, and 621 cm−1. For reference, the main peak of ZnO appears at 437 cm−1; [30] thus, we conclude that almost no crystalline ZnO phase existed in either Mn0 or Mn10. However, it is difficult to clearly assign the other peaks to specific metal or metal oxide species, as their Raman peak positions are often similar. For example, CuO typically shows peaks at 342 and 628 cm−1, [31] Mn2O3 at 652 cm−1, [32] and β-MnO2 at 667 cm−1. [32] Monoclinic ZrO2 exhibits peaks at 335 and 476 cm−1, [33] while tetragonal ZrO2 shows peaks at 292, 324, 407, 456, and 636 cm−1. [33] To further examine the effect of reduction, we compared the Raman spectra of Mn0 before and after H2 treatment. According to the results in Fig. 7 and Table 1, the as-prepared Mn0 contained approximately 50 wt% of CuO, which is fully reduced to metallic Cu after the treatment. Since metallic Cu is Raman-inactive, the Raman peaks originating from CuO should disappear or significantly decrease upon reduction. However, the peak at 621 cm−1 remained nearly unchanged by the H2 reduction, suggesting that this peak does not primarily originate from CuO. This implies that the contribution of CuO to the overall Raman spectrum is minimal, even before reduction. CuO and MnO x are dark-colored and strongly absorb visible light, which likely suppresses their Raman signals under 532 nm excitation. Therefore, the observed Raman spectra mainly reflect signals from Zn- and Zr-based components. Moreover, no noticeable change was observed between the spectra before and after hydrogen reduction, implying that the crystal structure of the Zn and Zr components is not significantly affected by the reduction treatment. Interestingly, the reported spectrum of Zn-doped ZrO2 (distorted tetragonal or cubic ZrO2) [34] contained peaks similar to those shown in Fig. 8. These results indicate that both Mn0 and Mn10 contained distorted tetragonal or cubic ZrO2 doped with hetero-metal species such as Zn and Cu. Taken together with the preceding discussion, these observations strongly suggest that Zn was fully incorporated into the metal oxide solid solution rather than existing as separate ZnO. In addition, the overall peak intensities decreased with Mn addition, suggesting a reduction in the crystallinity of Zn- and Zr-containing phases. To evaluate the oxidation state of constituent elements in the reduced catalysts, XPS/AES measurements were conducted ( Fig. 9). The sample was reduced at 300 °C in a 5 % H2/Ar stream. Although pretreatment at 275 °C would have been ideal, the structural configuration of the reduction apparatus may have caused a temperature difference between the catalyst and the measurement setting. As will be seen in the H2-TPR results ( Fig. 10), reduction was completed at temperatures below 250 °C. Taking this into consideration, a slightly higher temperature of 300 °C was selected as the pretreatment condition for reduction in the XPS/AES experiments. For Cu 2p3/2 (Fig. 9 a), a peak is observed at 932.7 eV and is attributed to Cu0 and/or Cu+ species. The absence of a noticeable satellite peak in the 940–945 eV region, which is characteristic of Cu2+, indicates that the population of Cu2+ species was negligible. In the Cu LMM Auger spectra (Fig. 9 b), the main peak appears at 918.3 eV. Regardless of the sample, α′Cu is 1851.0 eV, which is consistent with the presence of metallic Cu0 rather than Cu+. [35] In other words, the reduction process changed the Cu oxidation state from 2+ (Figs. 7, and S5a) to 0 (Figs. 9 a and 9 b). For Zn 2p3/2 (Fig. 9 c), a peak is observed at 1022.0 eV, which can be attributed to either Zn0 or Zn2+ species. However, in the Zn LMM Auger spectra (Fig. 9 d), the main peak appears at 988.7 eV. α′Zn is 2010.7 eV for all samples, which is characteristic of Zn2+, thereby indicating the predominant oxidation state is Zn2+. [36] In the Zr 3d spectra (Fig. 9 e), two peaks are consistently observed at 182.2 and 184.6 eV, corresponding to the Zr 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 components of Zr4+, [10] regardless of the catalyst type. In the Mn 2p3/2 region (Fig. 9 f), five peaks corresponding to Mn3+ (640.78, 641.57, 642.25, 643.21, and 643.83 eV) [37] were used for the fitting. In the spectra of the as-prepared catalysts (Figure S5b), the other peaks corresponding to Mn4+ (642.03, 642.81, 643.40, 644.10, and 644.88 eV) were also used for the fitting. [37] These results indicate that the Mn4+ species were completely reduced to Mn3+ by the hydrogen pretreatment at 300°C. According to the peak area analysis, the Mn3+ to Mn4+ population ratio in the as-prepared catalysts is approximately 2 (Figure S5b). The reducibility of Cu species was evaluated by H2-TPR (Fig. 10). According to the XPS/AES results (Figures 9 and S5), only Cu2+ and Mn4+ species were reduced. Given that the amount of Cu species in the catalyst is significantly higher than that of Mn species (Table 1), it is considered that the reduction features observed in the TPR profiles primarily reflect the reduction of Cu2+. For Mn0, a broad reduction feature is observed, which can be deconvoluted into three peaks, designated as α 1, α 2, and β. The α peaks are attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed Cu2+ species incorporated into the metal oxide supports. [38,39] Specifically, α 1 is typically observed for Cu2+ species interacting with ZrO₂, while α 2 is associated with Cu2+ species supported on γ-Al2O3, and the β peak corresponds to the reduction of conventional supported CuO species. [38,39] A detailed comparison of the TPR profiles for Mn0, Mn5, and Mn10 reveals that the α 1 contribution gradually decreases with increasing Mn content, while the α 2 and β peaks become more prominent. This trend suggests that Mn addition weakened the Cu-ZrO2 interaction (reflected in the decline of α 1) and strengthened the interaction between Cu and Mn species (reflected in the growth of α 2). The increase in the α 2 peak intensity may indicate the formation of Cu-Mn oxide interfaces. However, the formation of a spinel-type CuMn2O4 phase can be reasonably excluded for Mn5 and Mn10. As shown in Figure S6, Cu species in CuMn2O4 are typically reduced at temperatures above 225 °C under identical TPR conditions, whereas such high-temperature reduction peaks are not observed in Fig. 10. In addition, the XRD patterns of Mn5 and Mn10 exhibit no diffraction peaks assignable to CuMn2O4 or other crystalline Mn-containing phases. These results collectively indicate that the formation of CuMn2O4 does not occur in the present Mn-containing catalysts, and that the observed α 2 peak is more likely associated with Cu-Mn surface interactions rather than bulk spinel formation. According to Tanaka et al., the reduction peak position of Cu species strongly bound to Mn oxides closely matches that of the α 2 peak, [40] further supporting this interpretation. In the Mn5 and Mn10 samples, the amount of CuO was approximately 12-fold and 5-fold greater than that of MnO2, respectively (Table 1). Considering the significant excess of Cu species and the inherent sensitivity limits of H2-TPR, it is difficult to clearly identify the reduction peak corresponding to the Mn4+ → Mn3+ transition. Therefore, the contribution of Mn reduction may be overlapped or obscured by the dominant Cu-related reduction features. 3.5 Linking catalyst structure to the reaction pathway We now turn to a detailed examination of the catalyst structure, with particular attention to the chemical states of the constituent elements. Based on the XPS/AES (Fig. 9), XRD (Fig. 7), and Raman (Fig. 8) results, it is confirmed that for the as-prepared catalysts the Cu species existed as CuO, and the Zn and Zr species as Zn-doped ZrO2. Among these species, only Cu was reduced under the applied conditions and existed as metallic Cu nanoparticles on the reduced catalyst. Regarding the Mn species, based on the XPS analysis (Figure S5), the as-prepared catalysts contained both Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, suggesting the presence of Mn2O3 and MnO2. According to the XRD results (Fig. 7), the manganese oxide seems to be amorphous. After hydrogen reduction, the Mn species existed exclusively as Mn3+ (Fig. 9), indicating that Mn4+ was reduced to Mn3+, but not further to Mn2+. The resulting phase is likely Mn2O3. For our Cu-based catalysts, the crystallite size of Cu (D Cu111, Table 1) was found to decrease upon Mn addition. This is consistent with the fact that the pre-exponential factor increased upon Mn addition (see Section 3.3 ). This difference in Cu size is reflected in the schematic image ( Fig. 11). Hence, the Mn species contributed to controlling the growth of Cu particles, suggesting that Mn and Cu species were in close proximity. From the contact time study (Fig. 5), it was revealed that Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 follows a sequential reaction pathway, regardless of whether Mn species is added or not. The sequential pathway consists of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (Eq. 1), followed by the decomposition of the formed methanol to CO (the reverse of Eq. 3). The reaction route is depicted in the schematic image (Fig. 11). Furthermore, the contact time study (Fig. 5) demonstrated that Mn addition suppresses the undesirable methanol decomposition. To the best of our knowledge, this phenomenon is reported here for the first time. In the schematic image (Fig. 11), this suppression effect is expressed by changing the thickness of the arrows. The reason for the suppression of methanol decomposition remains unclear in the present study. For instance, drawing on our previous studies of Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, [10,41] it is possible that the addition of Mn species promoted the amorphization of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 crystallites. This structural modification may have weakened the adsorption of methanol as a reaction intermediate, which in turn contributed to the observed enhancement in methanol selectivity. Further investigations using model catalyst systems based on Cu-Mn mixed oxides are planned to clarify this point. 4 Conclusion This study aimed to investigate the effect of Mn addition on the structure and catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts for methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2. The as-prepared catalysts consisted primarily of CuO, which was reduced to metallic Cu after hydrogen treatment. In contrast, Zn and Zr were not reduced and remained in their oxidized forms. Regarding Mn, the as-prepared catalysts contained both Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, whereas only Mn3+—likely present as amorphous Mn2O3—remained after reduction. H₂-TPR results further indicated an interaction between Cu and Mn species. The Mn-containing catalyst achieved a methanol yield of 9.3 % at 4 MPa and 250 °C, compared to 6.3 % for the Mn-free catalyst. Despite this significant improvement, the apparent activation energy for CO2 consumption remained essentially unchanged upon Mn addition, suggesting that the reaction pathway over Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 was not fundamentally altered. The reaction tests clearly indicate that CO₂ hydrogenation proceeds via a stepwise pathway of CO2 → methanol → CO, regardless of the presence or absence of Mn. These findings imply that Mn mainly enhances catalytic activity by promoting the formation of more active sites. Specifically, the presence of Mn suppressed the growth of Cu crystallites and increased the pre-exponential factor in the Arrhenius equation, reflecting improved dispersion of metallic Cu and many active sites. Furthermore, Mn addition was observed to have a slight suppressive effect on CO formation resulting from methanol decomposition. These results demonstrate that Mn serves as a structural promoter that enhances Cu dispersion and catalytic performance, while also slightly suppressing undesired methanol decomposition, without altering the fundamental CO2 hydrogenation pathway over Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts are well known for promoting methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation. In this study, the effect of Mn addition to Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 was investigated. XPS analysis revealed that the as-prepared catalysts contained both Mn3 + and Mn4+ species, whereas only Mn3+ was present after hydrogen reduction at 300 °C. These results suggest that Mn species existed as Mn2O3 under reaction conditions. Furthermore, the addition of Mn led to a decrease in the crystallite size of metallic Cu, indicating that Mn species promoted the dispersion of Cu species. This increased dispersion is considered to enhance the number of active sites on the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst. In addition, the presence of Mn species enhanced the methanol selectivity by suppressing the undesirable methanol decomposition to CO. As a result, the Mn-modified Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst achieved a methanol yield of 9.3 % at 4 MPa and 250 °C.
